Assert Input is Safe for Beginner Users (Comprehensive Validation)

Source: R/utilities.R
assert_beginner_safe.Rd

**Internal L1 Helper.** Centralized validation function that checks common input assumptions and provides educational error messages for beginners. Ensures consistency across all package functions.

This function enforces the "beginner-first" philosophy by catching common mistakes early with helpful guidance.

Usage

assert_beginner_safe(
  x,
  type = c("numeric", "data.frame", "character", "logical", "factor", "integer",
    "matrix"),
  allow_na = FALSE,
  min_length = 1,
  max_length = Inf,
  min_value = -Inf,
  max_value = Inf,
  allow_infinite = FALSE,
  arg_name = "x",
  context = NULL
)

Arguments

x

Object to validate

type

Character. Expected type: "numeric", "data.frame", "character", "logical", "factor", "integer", or "matrix"

allow_na

Logical. Are NA values allowed? Default FALSE.

min_length

Integer. Minimum length/nrow required. Default 1.

max_length

Integer. Maximum length/nrow allowed. Default Inf.

min_value

Numeric. Minimum value allowed (for numeric types). Default -Inf.

max_value

Numeric. Maximum value allowed (for numeric types). Default Inf.

allow_infinite

Logical. Are Inf/-Inf allowed? Default FALSE.

arg_name

Character. Name of the argument being validated (for error messages). Default "x".

context

Character. Context for the error (e.g., "t-test", "correlation"). Helps provide more specific guidance.

Value

Invisible TRUE if all checks pass. Errors otherwise.

Details

**What this checks:** - Type correctness (numeric, data.frame, etc.) - NA/NaN/Inf handling - Length/dimension constraints - Value range constraints (for numeric) - Common beginner mistakes

**Educational error messages:** Every error explains: 1. What went wrong 2. Why it's a problem 3. How to fix it 4. What to check in the data

**Philosophy:** This function embodies the consumeR philosophy: "Silence is a bug." We catch problems early and guide the user to solutions.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Basic type check
x <- c(1, 2, 3)
assert_beginner_safe(x, type = "numeric")  # Pass

# With constraints
assert_beginner_safe(x,
  type = "numeric",
  min_length = 2,
  min_value = 0,
  max_value = 10
)

# Data frame with NA check
df <- data.frame(a = 1:5, b = 6:10)
assert_beginner_safe(df,
  type = "data.frame",
  min_length = 3,  # min 3 rows
  arg_name = "data"
)

# Will error with educational message
assert_beginner_safe(c(1, NA, 3),
  type = "numeric",
  allow_na = FALSE,
  context = "correlation analysis"
)
} # }
